As a reference in the "Against" category, I found @damianavila comment https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/3605#issuecomment-20854278

> If I have a large ipynb with all my mardown cells un-rendered (which is great!), save it in this state, and close it... when I reopen it all the markdown cells are rendered, and I actually would want to _keep my un-rendered state_...

(and in fact this small inconsistency caused me at first to suspect a bug: before discovering that I had to run `Shift-Enter` to "compile" cells, I thought that I had to reload the entire notebook page...)

There's also @minrk anwsering @jakobgager https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/3605#issuecomment-20829636

> > If I just move out of a heading cell its not get rendered as heading cells. It needs to be executed.
> 
> I think that's by design

On 29 April 2014 03:04, Pierre Haessig notifications@github.com wrote:

> I believe that the use-case that supports the current behavior is the one
> of _"complex markdown cells"_ that may take a long time to render,
> prohibiting the automatic rendering.
> 
> Actually, it's for documents with lots of consecutive markdown cells. As
> cells render and de-render their size changes, making the cells below them
> jump up and down, which gets annoying when editing a long document. People
> wanted a way to work on multiple unrendered cells, and then render them all
> at once.

Being able to have multiple unrendered markdown cells is a really important
and common situation when building long narratives. Forcing them to render
upon entering command made mades it extremely difficult to move content
around. That was one of our main goals in the 2.0 work on the modal UI.

Thanks for the feedback. It' true that I had never felt annoyed by Markdown cells changing size when rendered. So it's not an issue of rendering complexity/time as I thought it could be.

Now, what I don't understand is the link between : 1) the change of size at rendering, and 2) the ability to move cells up and down. Because I can move the cells both in rendered and unrendered state. And there is no size jumping in either cases. I think I'm just missing the advantage of moving cells unrendered.

Also, going a bit deeper, what annoys me right now is that there are in effect 3 modes (for Markdown and heading cells) instead of the two (Edit and Command) being advertised:
1. Edit mode
2. Command mode, unrendered (which I feel a bit extraneous ;-) )
3. Command mode, rendered

and more modes mean more transitions to learn...

Maybe as a compromise solution, the automatic rendering could be activated for heading cells, since the size jump should be relatively small with those ?

I guess there is no point in keeping this issue open. Although I feel that the immediate rendering is "philosophically" better (because it _tightens the user interaction loop_ like in Bret Victor's Inventing on Principle video), I suspect I'm getting used to the new behavior...

Thanks for your answers.
